Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ionic Transistor Devices for Sensing and Controlled Actuation - An Integrated Research, Teaching and Community Outreach Program

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award focuses on the development of a novel active material formed from integrating the ionic properties of a bio-derived membrane and a conducting polymer membrane. The scientific goal of this project is the development of a hybrid membrane that can respond to low power electrical signal or low concentration chemical trigger and perform electromechanical work using ambient chemical gradients. This hybrid membrane, referred to as Bio-derived Ionic Transistor (BIT) functions as the fundamental unit in sensing and actuation systems. A BIT device comprising a conducting polymer and a bio-derived membrane (BLM with proteins) will be fabricated, characterized using a coupled model and optimized into a robust transistor. The scientific goal of this research proposal will be achieved by addressing the following questions: What is/are the (i) limiting conditions (geometrical, chemoelectrical, mechanical) for ion transport, (ii) relationship between the output, gating signal and input (static, dynamic), (iii) open-loop and closed-loop operation (transfer function, sensitivity, disturbance rejection, stability and performance limitation) and (iv) fabrication constraints and scalability.

If successful, this CAREER research project will lead to the development of a robust real-time sensing array constructed using BIT devices that can detect chemical and bioelectrical signals using commercially available proteins and be applicable in healthcare, national defense and homeland security. This project will also lead to the development of an artificial muscle using the chemomechanical properties of the BIT device. This CAREER award will enable the PI to build an inter-disciplinary research program in Polymer Mechatronic Materials, promote participation of women in engineering, integrate this research work in to undergraduate and graduate curriculum at Virginia Commonwealth University through Active Learning and disseminate knowledge in this field to the general public and school students in the Commonwealth through continuous engagements with the Science Museum of Virginia at Richmond, Virginia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research award demonstrated the materials architecture, composition and algorithm required for a sensor that can measure electrical signals of cells (e.g., neurons) without causing any physical damage. The material required for this sensor is a flexible polymer (polypyrrole) that can conduct electrical signals, and simultaneously interact with sodium, potassium and calcium ions that cells exchange its immediate environment. The research activities of this award resulted in the following outcomes towards the design and development of a bioelectrical/chemical sensor – (1) a mathematical expression to relate the input and output to the polypyrrole membrane and a cell; (2) relationship between fabrication conditions of the polymer (size, volume, density) and the measurable output from the sensor; (3) a method to fabricate the sensor at the tip of a nanoscale glass electrode and its application in live animal models. The scientific outcomes were disseminated as peer-reviewed journal publications and a broader application of the mathematical models were discussed. For example, the mathematical models developed for the conducting polymer and ionic transistor are applicable for polymer actuators and polymer electrodes for batteries, besides sensors, and the discussions presented in our journal articles outlined the design guidelines and compromises for creating a robust actuator/energy storage device. The research activities of this award also led to the development of a novel technique to create templated conducting polymer membrane with higher charge storage capacity, and its application as battery electrodes.

This award supported two women graduate students towards their doctoral degrees in engineering, and three undergraduate students as summer interns in the PI’s laboratory. In addition, the PI collaborated with Science Museum of Virginia in 2011 and designed demonstration kits on smart materials that can be used by the museum staff. This award also supported the creation of a new graduate course on polymer smart materials for students in engineering at VCU and OSU during the performance period of this award.
